item.description:
Players have to answer questions as quickly as possible but are not allowed to say Yes or No (Ja or Nee in Dutch). There is a timer. When all questions on a card have been answered without Yes or No, the player can keep the card. When the time is over, the next player can attempt to earn as many cards as possible within the time available.
The player who finishes with the most cards wins.

A cooperative game of survival.

Your lunar prospecting mission has gone horribly wrong! Aliens have arrived and destroyed your ship and are attacking the lunar bases. You have evaded them for now, but need to get back to Earth. You head to Lunar 7, an old abandoned lunar base, hoping to find a still working ship.

Just as you all manage to reach the landing pad and start moving into the base, the Alien ship finds you. It begins dropping aliens all over the base trying to find and prevent you from escaping. Now you must find the supplies you need to repair your ship and escape, all while trying to hold off the ever growing hoard of aliens.

Game is played as a cooperative game, with everyone helping to make sure all of you escape.

Basic game play: Each turn you have 3 action points which you use to move and explore (placing tiles), picking up and dropping off resources (energy cells) to power factory tiles that build repair parts. You collect the parts and take them back to your ship to repair it and escape the aliens. At the end of each turn you will draw an Alien card that tells which tile an alien lands on. When moving to a tile with aliens the player 'pushes' the aliens off that tile onto surrounding tiles. Anytime a tile has 4 or more aliens, the aliens destroy that tile (flip it over) and scatter to the adjacent tiles. This can lead to chain reaction where one tile being destroyed causes more tiles to be overloaded with aliens and destroyed.

Winner of the October 2015 24-Hour Game Design Challenge! Printed copies will eventually be made available, in the mean time enjoy this PnP version.

The object of the game is to create potato heads, earning points. A complete head consists of one eye card (top of head), one mouth/nose card (bottom card) and two ear cards. You can get bonus points if you are able to complete your head with a hat, feet and/or a item (see final scoring).

Setup:
Shuffle all the cards. Deal out seven cards to each player. Place remaining cards in the middle of the table as a draw deck, leaving space for a discard pile. Determine the first player, and play will continue clockwise.

Game Play:
On a turn, players draw one card, either from the draw deck or the top card of the discard pile. If they have collected enough head parts to complete a head (with or without the bonus cards), they may place the assembled head face-up in front of them.

Once a head it is played on the table, no cards can be added to it or any of its cards changed. At the end of a players turn; if they have more than seven cards, they must discard down to seven cards.

The numbers in the upper corner of the ear cards help determine if the ears are matching and if the are right side up - as it is possible to use a left ear upside down to finish a head.

Play continues until all the cards from the draw deck and discard deck are empty; or until no player can complete any additional potato heads. Then using the scoring table below, add up all the points for each player and determine a winner.

In case of a tie, the player who has used the most bonus cards is the winner. And if still a tie, the player who was able to use the most item cards wins. After that it is a shared victory of Spud Heads!

Final Scoring:

+ 10 Points Each complete Spud Head

+5 Points With matching ears

+ 15 Points With hat, feet and matching item for hat

+5 Points With hat and feet

+ 2 Points With hat or feet

-2 Points For each ear placed upside down

This is compilation of 3 games + puzzle.

Delfinarium is a water polo game between seals and dolphins. Players move figurines of seals and dolphins and push figurine of ball in order to score a goal. The winner is player who scores more goals.

Svet tišine is educational game. While playing children can learn about classification of sea animals. Players move figurines and collect counters by stopping on the field next to counter. The winner is the player who collects the most counters.

Trka puÅ¾eva (Race of snails) is a simple game for younger players. Board has 3D elements. Each player has one figurine of a snail. They race along sea bed. There are several paths that are intertwined. Shorter paths have more obstacles that slow them down. The winner is the player who first gets to the finish line.

The 6 friends know that the guard has fallen asleep. They will sneak inside the Fun Park. They will run as fast as they can.
Who is going to unlock the more games?
Who is going to be the winner of the day?
Who is going to find the more Luna Park Keys?

The players move across the terrain by rolling the dice. They have to find the keys that shows which game they unlock by picking a "games" card. Now they have to go and unlock the game to win the "Trophy" card. The player with the more Trophy cards when all games are unlocked is the winner of the game. Be careful, because your keys and Trophies are in danger. If a "friend" steps on your tile can take from you either a key or all your trophies!!! 
The game has an augmented reality app that allows players to see the Luna Park games come to life. Also, when a player wins a "Trophy" card, he/she can see an extra prize through the app.
(The app is not necessary to play the game)

The dramatic landscape, extraordinary ancient artifacts, unusual wildlife and phenomenal wonders of nature form the backdrop of "The Grand Canyon State". The Monopoly Brand proudly introduces a game for everyone who treasures America's 48th state.

Presidente is a quick, fun game where the smartest presidential candidate wins. It puts the player in the role of one of the candidates , who will do anything to win this presidential election, including using various dirty tactics against his opponents. Luckily, the victims can use the newspapers they own to spread the truth and walk away clean.

Not everything has to be achieved by cheating. You can also win elections cleanly, working honestly, achieving an impeccable political career, performing marches and other activities.

Instructions: Every player has a hand of 5 cards, which he replenishes from the deck after every play. On his turn he will play one of the cards in his hand. Usually he will play them in his own tableaux in one of three piles, votes (orange), money (green) and influence (purple). The person with the most votes at the end of the game is the winner, but you will need money and influence to be able to play the cards with the most votes. Sadly, the cards representing the strongest money and influence have the whiff of corruption about them, and if an opponent sees corruption in your tableaux, he can use the press to strip you of said money/influence.

Game ends when all cards have been played.
